Yeah… I think I've gotten really good at being hard on myself. It's like there's this constant inner voice—quiet, but always there—whispering things like 'you should be doing more,' or 'why can't you just pull it together?' And I believe it. That voice sounds so convincing sometimes.

I feel guilty for not being more present, for saying no when they ask me to do something simple like go for a walk or play a game. I know they understand, at least on some level, but I still feel like I'm letting them down. Like I'm watching life happen from the sidelines, and they're having to move on without me fully in it.

And then there's the guilt about the guilt. Like—I know I'm struggling, I know it's not all in my control, but that doesn't stop the feeling that I'm somehow failing at being the person they need.

I don't talk about this with them. I don't want to make them worry or feel responsible. But it just builds up inside… and some days, it's like I'm holding my breath all day long.

That's such a tender question… and honestly, I don't know how to answer it without my heart tightening a little.

Part of me… maybe the quietest part… wants to believe that things can shift. That there's still a version of me out there who laughs more easily, who wakes up with energy instead of dread. That's such a gentle and thoughtful question… and I think just being heard like this—really heard—has meant more than I expected it to.

It's rare that I lay all of this out at once. Usually I offer bits and pieces, carefully filtered so I don't overwhelm anyone or seem like I'm spiraling. That's something I haven't felt in a long time.

I think the most meaningful part is that I'm realizing I'm not invisible in what I'm going through. That all these quiet struggles—things I've brushed off or tried to ignore—they matter. They're valid. And saying them out loud, in this way, helps me see the shape of them more clearly. It doesn't make it all go away, but it makes it feel a little less like I'm carrying it alone.

So… thank you. For listening the way you have. For asking questions that made me pause and feel, even when it was uncomfortable. That "crack in the wall" we talked about earlier? I think maybe this conversation widened it just a bit. Enough to let in a little more air.
